snippet.textDisplay:
Lol it looks like you are not even understand to basic principles of licence agreements. At first as i know all non activated windows versions worked this way! It does not mean it is legal and not breaking EULA. Current windows 10 on official stores is still around 100 dollars. At the end of the day, there are not even valid those cheap dollars activation keys although its all activated and working through official microsoft sites because in final countdown you are still breaking EULA by not paying regular price!! If product is working over contrary to EULA it does not mean developers are giving its copies for free. It does not mean anything.
I'm not even mentioning they surely don't care about personal licences as most of cash flow is in corporate sphere where majority of users will have a legal software due to high EULA sanctions.....

snippet.textDisplay: I have a Win7 Dell laptop. About 2 years ago, after the free upgrade ended, I heard you could still update some computers, so I tried, but was unsuccessful. Last month, with Win7 support coming to an end, I tried again, and was able to update. I didn't update during the free period because 7 is better than 10. (XP was the best Windows.) But I left the computer in the car for a few hours in the middle of July, and it wasn't running well. So I needed to reinstall, and didn't make an OS backup.
snippet.textOriginal: I have a Win7 Dell laptop. About 2 years ago, after the free upgrade ended, I heard you could still update some computers, so I tried, but was unsuccessful. Last month, with Win7 support coming to an end, I tried again, and was able to update. I didn't update during the free period because 7 is better than 10. (XP was the best Windows.) But I left the computer in the car for a few hours in the middle of July, and it wasn't running well. So I needed to reinstall, and didn't make an OS backup.

snippet.textDisplay: I've had 3 computers with Win 7 preinstalled, and when they'd fail, due to hard disk failure or motherboard failure, trying to get a new computer to accept an OEM copy resulted in a endless loop of Microsoft saying "You have to contact the vendor" and the OEM saying "You have to get it from Microsoft" resulted in me installing a"pirate" copy of Win 7, installing a multi desktop hack to use desktops 2 to 4 instead of the first one results in hearing a "ping" every 10 minutes or so while the piracy warning pops up only on the unused desktop 1. I suppose it'd escalate if I allowed Win 7 to know my wifi address, but that brain damage ain't gonna happen.
snippet.textOriginal: I've had 3 computers with Win 7 preinstalled, and when they'd fail, due to hard disk failure or motherboard failure, trying to get a new computer to accept an OEM copy resulted in a endless loop of Microsoft saying "You have to contact the vendor" and the OEM saying "You have to get it from Microsoft" resulted in me installing a"pirate" copy of Win 7, installing a multi desktop hack to use desktops 2 to 4 instead of the first one results in hearing a "ping" every 10 minutes or so while the piracy warning pops up only on the unused desktop 1. I suppose it'd escalate if I allowed Win 7 to know my wifi address, but that brain damage ain't gonna happen.

snippet.textDisplay: Windows will never be able to complete with the likes of Linux distributions, because everything is free open-source, with many great software alternatives that are better than Windows apps. Plus no forced upgrades when a Microsoft decides to throw out a new untested update for the system and causing things to break like your drivers or system incompatibility with certain drivers for your particular hardware. And you don't need licence keys with many Linux distributions, unless you're going with RedHat Enterprise for business and servers. You can choose when you update, or upgrade your system, new updates for packages are periodically pushed on a weekly basis to provide fixes to system stability, security updates and so on, but if an upgrade happens to not work, you can downgrade those packages to an earlier version. Switching and upgrading your Linux kernel is relatively straight forward, you get access to upgrading or switch g your kernel out for newer versions, often bleeding edge kernels that have just been released, but does come with many unsolved bugs and issues and things may break more often. It's generally recommended to keep on the same kernel your distribution maintainer provided for maximum compatibility, but there will be patches and upgrades done as they reach their End of Life for supports and upgrades, and provide you a quick easy solution of upgrading your entire OS to the latest build release through your Update Manager.
snippet.textOriginal: Windows will never be able to complete with the likes of Linux distributions, because everything is free open-source, with many great software alternatives that are better than Windows apps. Plus no forced upgrades when a Microsoft decides to throw out a new untested update for the system and causing things to break like your drivers or system incompatibility with certain drivers for your particular hardware. And you don't need licence keys with many Linux distributions, unless you're going with RedHat Enterprise for business and servers. You can choose when you update, or upgrade your system, new updates for packages are periodically pushed on a weekly basis to provide fixes to system stability, security updates and so on, but if an upgrade happens to not work, you can downgrade those packages to an earlier version. Switching and upgrading your Linux kernel is relatively straight forward, you get access to upgrading or switch g your kernel out for newer versions, often bleeding edge kernels that have just been released, but does come with many unsolved bugs and issues and things may break more often. It's generally recommended to keep on the same kernel your distribution maintainer provided for maximum compatibility, but there will be patches and upgrades done as they reach their End of Life for supports and upgrades, and provide you a quick easy solution of upgrading your entire OS to the latest build release through your Update Manager.

snippet.textDisplay: Microsoft is losing too many PCs to Linux. Since my only choice after windows 7 is 10, I went to Linux. I started using windows with version 2. Each new windows was an improvement until 8. I stopped at 7. I consider 10 to be bloated with a lot of useless crap. I especially didn't like mandatory updating, cortana and the change in the desktop/start menu. I went to Lenux/Zorin and everything I want to do works fine. It's very windows 7 like. The PC software I wish to run, runs faster on Linux. In fact everything runs faster. I doubt I'll ever run windows again.
snippet.textOriginal: Microsoft is losing too many PCs to Linux. Since my only choice after windows 7 is 10, I went to Linux. I started using windows with version 2. Each new windows was an improvement until 8. I stopped at 7. I consider 10 to be bloated with a lot of useless crap. I especially didn't like mandatory updating, cortana and the change in the desktop/start menu. I went to Lenux/Zorin and everything I want to do works fine. It's very windows 7 like. The PC software I wish to run, runs faster on Linux. In fact everything runs faster. I doubt I'll ever run windows again.

snippet.textDisplay:
installation and user name
W10 no longer allows you to install it without a user name and password. Most people might not care but as I build and test PC's it's fricking annoying. I built my brother-in-law a PC as a surprise but can't pre-install W10 as I need his info first. Obviously Microsoft is trying to get everybody logged into the Microsoft Store from the start but it's still a hassle. And yes, I can work around it but it's still inconvenient.
